awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Developing Light-Controlled Mixing to Advance Energy Efficient Wastewater Treatment by Oxygenic Photogranules
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project includes significantly decreased costs for energy, decreased negative environmental impacts, and improved public health due to a new method for treating wastewater, known as oxygenic photogranule (OPG) technology, using microbes and natural processes.  This process requires less electricity to provide oxygen for treatment ordinarily used in treating wastewater, as well as using atmospheric carbon dioxide.  This could be retrofitted in the infrastructure in developed countries and could be included in new wastewater treatment facilities. For regions where wastewater treatment is absent or inadequate, sanitation via the OPG technology improves public health and the environment at a lower cost than conventional technology. This process has been demonstrated successfully at small scales, but scale-up and implementation requires the scientific and technical advancements of the proposed PFI-RP project. This project will include significant advanced training of future engineers and scientists, including underrepresented groups.  Outreach to students, increased graduate study opportunities for women and minorities, and technology transfer are also benefits to society at large. 

The proposed project is critical for developing commercial implementation of the new self-aerating OPG process for sustainable wastewater treatment. The OPG process has the potential to solve wastewater treatment challenges in both developing and developed countries. Despite prior advancements in photogranulation knowledge, and success of bench-scale OPG systems, process scale-up in a natural light setting recently failed after initial success. The PIs hypothesize that this outcome was due to photoinhibition of photogranulation, which has not been studied in previous OPG research. Objectives of the proposed research are to a) investigate the photoinhibition phenomenon by studying the photochemical capacity and the photosynthesis range of the OPG process, and b) to develop a fluid mixing and irradiance-based method to limit photoinhibition of OPG reactors. Integrating these critical new knowledge sets is expected to yield an innovative irradiance-based mixing scheme to control photoinhibition and support adequate oxygenic photosynthesis. Research methods include operation of batch and continuous flow reactors under different irradiance and mixing conditions and modeling of reactor hydrodynamics and OPG transport. These activities will significantly improve knowledge of photogranulation and enhance the translation of a new wastewater treatment technology to a commercial scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wastewater treatment is an essential safeguard for public and environmental health. However, it comes with significant resource requirements as well as carbon footprints. Currently in the U.S., wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) consume greater than a third of the energy used by the municipality, with aeration operation utilizing up to 80% of this energy. Aeration also accounts for WWTPs being one of the largest greenhouse emitters with their direct emissions estimated at 1.6% of global inventory―The emissions will be significantly greater if indirect emissions are included.

This Partnerships-for-Innovation (PFI) project bestowed opportunities to researchers who aim to advance and ultimately commercialize oxygenic photogranules (OPGs) for wastewater treatment.

Oxygenic Photogranules (OPGs) are microbial granules that result from symbiosis of O2-producing phototrophic microbes and other bacteria that possess essential traits for wastewater treatment. Hence, using OPGs offers potential to replace or strongly reduce aeration for wastewater treatment by employing natural photosynthetic aeration while fixing carbon.

This PFI project specifically aimed to better understand OPGs’ photochemical (thus, O2-producing) capacity and the movement of OPG biomass and water in reactor systems that determine the interaction of OPG biomass with light. These two points are considered the most basic knowledge that must be available for the team to scale up the OPG system for industrialization. To attain these goals, this PFI project was formed with interdisciplinary research collaboration among PIs from Environmental Engineering and Mechanical Engineering as well as partnerships with industry collaborators and mentors.

The pandemic impacted the project in many aspects, including limited access to laboratories and risk associated with working with wastewater. However, the team’s resilience as well as flexibility and supplemental support from the NSF PFI program made it possible for the team to go through and complete the project.

During the project, the team also learned a new technical barrier for OPG scale-up, photolimitation in larger OPG reactors treating turbid wastewater. The team spent substantial time and efforts to learn about the phenomena and overcome the challenges. These efforts indeed resulted in additional inventions on OPGs, including a derivative technology, NaturaFloc. The team is pleased to share the meaningful progress that has been made on recent OPG pilot operations. More information of these outcomes is presented in the project report and will be reported via academic journal publications.

This interdisciplinary project broadened participation by engaging many participants from diverse backgrounds and education levels. First, Dr. Joseph Gikonyo, who has been a pivotal element in this project, finished his PhD on OPG with support from this PFI project and is continuing to spearhead on OPG scale-up for commercialization. Dr. Gikonyo completed two NSF I-Corps, the first time as Entrepreneurial Lead for OPG and later Technical Lead for NaturaFloc, indicating his devotion to this project and gaining a significant level of entrepreneurial education and experiences. PIs also appreciate his leadership in two large-scale OPG pilot studies during this project. His taking lead on 30,000 L pilot reactor, which resulted from retrofitting an old unused trickling filter pilot, gave an outstanding example for tying education and hands-on research. Thanks to the availability of this large pilot, the team is currently able to test OPG in this semi-industry scale setting, invaluable resource in OPG industrialization.

The project supported Dr. Sampath Rachakonda, a postdoc in Mechanical Engineering, who took lead on CFD modeling, especially on flow velocity and particle location, the results of which became a significant component in the development of an OPG mixing module. PIs are pleased to report that the project supported three PhD students (including two female students) who are currently continuing their academic endeavor as faculty, postdoc, and student. Additionally, this research supported and engaged two MS students, several undergraduate students, and high school students and most of these students are female and with diverse ethnicities.

The team’s academic endeavors resulted in several research articles published via high-impact journals. The OPG research group also filed three additional patent applications for OPG and NaturaFloc, strengthening their effort on technology transfer. The team is currently working with multiple industry partners and mentors who have contributed to the progress and accomplishment of the current project. Working with these industry partners and from the lessons from NSF I-Corps training, we learned that commercialization is a pivotal way to realize the potential of OPG-technology borne in the university laboratory, and the team is strongly interested in outlicensing the OPG technology as well as forming own startup.

Overall, the project team is excited about the progress that has been made on OPG scale-up and commercialization endeavors accomplished by the current PFI project. It is our understanding that full-scale pilot evidence will be the most critical piece in OPG technology translation and for this goal, the team will continue to work with industry partners, especially innovative and early technology adopters.
